Award.AwardTitle: IRFP: Eco-Evolutionary Dynamics of Allee Effects and their Mitigating Adaptations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Research Fellowship Program enables U.S. scientists and engineers to conduct nine to twenty-four months of research abroad. The program's awards provide opportunities for joint research, and the use of unique or complementary facilities, expertise and experimental conditions abroad.

This award will support a twenty-four-month research fellowship by Dr. Allison K. Shaw to work with Dr. Hanna Kokko at the Australian National University (Canberra, Australia) and with Dr. Michael Neubert at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (Massachusetts).

An Allee effect describes a positive relationship between an individual's fitness and the number of its conspecifics, the most common example being an individual's increased chance of finding mates at higher population density. It may be tempting to predict that any adaptation that allows an individual to overcome an Allee effect should have been selected for, since Allee effects negatively impact an individual's fitness at low density. However, this may not be the case if periods of low density were rare during a species' evolutionary history. Furthermore, some types of adaptations (including dispersal) may actually exacerbate Allee effects in a population that has been artificially reduced to a low density. Before we can predict the dynamics of low-density populations, we need to develop a solid understanding of how Allee effects and their mitigating adaptations interact. The two broad objectives of this research are 1) to build a theoretical framework integrating Allee effects and counter adaptations in an eco-evolutionary context, and 2) to apply the findings to predict dynamics in the specific example of invasive species.

The proposed research will contribute fundamentally to our understanding of the dynamics governing populations at low density, which has potential applications in the control of invasive pest species, management of fisheries, and protection of endangered species. This research will also foster valuable international collaboration between the PI and research groups at the Australian National University, other institutions within Australia, and the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An 'Allee effect' describes the situation where an individual's fitness increases with population density or number. The most common example of an Allee effect is that individuals are more likely to find mates at higher population density. Allee effects can be detrimental to a population that is already small in size. By changing how they move, individuals can potentially improve their mating success ameliorate an Allee effect, to the benefit of themselves and the population. Although it may be tempting to predict that any adaptation that allows an individual to overcome an Allee effect should have been selected for, the modeling research conducted in this project demonstrated that this is not always the case. We found that for a population at constant density, evolution generally led to movement behaviors that increased mate finding and alleviated the Allee effect. However in the case of a spreading population (e.g. reintroduced or invasive species) where density varies, evolution led to one of two outcomes. When competition for resources was low, individuals evolved movement that improved their mating success, ameliorated the Allee effect, and caused the population to spread slower than without evolution. However when competition for resources was high, individual evolved movement that decreased their mating success, amplified the Allee effect, and caused the population to spread faster than without evolution.

Although individuals move in part to find mates, mating and movement can interact in a variety of ways for different species. In some organisms, individuals mate soon after birth and before they move, in others individuals mate as they move and eventually settle, and in others still individuals complete most of their movement, settle and find a mate nearby. Our modeling results demonstrated that the relative timing of mating and dispersal determines whether males and females travel the same distance or difference ones (called 'sex-biased dispersal'), and the degree and direction of sex-biased dispersal. Furthermore, in populations where individuals can mate before or during movement, the population can spread an order of magnitude faster than in populations where can individuals only mate after dispersal.

How individuals move also has consequences at the population level: movement determines in large part the spatial, genetic and social structure of populations as well as their connectivity. Our modeling results demonstrated that movement behavior that evolved as best for individuals was less than ideal for population: it reduced population size and connectivity. Furthermore, we found that the conditions that are associated with conservation concerns in the first place (small and fragmented habitats inhabited by a species with a low birth rate) are also the ones that are most likely to lead to suboptimal dispersal traits.

This grant directly funded the training of a postdoctoral researcher and indirectly enabled the training and mentoring of an undergraduate student on a research project. This grant fostered valuable international collaboration between the PI and research groups in Australia, the US and Europe, and provided funding for the presentation of research findings at international conferences and universities in Australia, the US and Europe.
